is designed and developed by the Madrid-based design studio Studiopepe, which has already been awarded for its projects such as the Ora&Pri hotel in Barcelona, and the 3D restaurant, and the 3D. A futuristic work is the “Project Electric Dream”. The studio's co-founder, Piero Lissoni, who comes from a small town near Venice, said: “The new house was designed around the idea of a 'ghost' electricity, which we are increasingly losing and which, however, we can still feel and breathe - and feel, for example, in the way in which lighting is projected in the house.” Lissoni added that this was one of the main points that inspired the Italian brand and the Spanish luxury furniture boutique Marset.
Marset and Studiopepe have already collaborated in the past year and now continue with the lighting “Sunshine” table lamp. With an unconventional shape, this light becomes a small icon of the space and offers a unique sensation of warmth and tranquility. Project PI has been conceived as the starting point of a series of “scenarios” for a future Marset brand image. The project focuses on both the furniture and lighting components, which are placed in different rooms and interact in an integrated way. The Spanish company continues to focus on projects that use innovative materials and technologies and look to the future of home design for years to come.

CO2017-0001-0006-9425 Mar074 (1)Mar074 (3)Mar074 (3) 3rd person narrative of one of the characters, but the rest of the book is written in the 1st person. (See the last entry of the review) But the plot has an overall 3rd person narrator. But the main character is writing letters, so that makes the third person narrative more interesting. It’s almost like an epistolary novel (one written in the form of letters). I’m still not sure that works for 2017. But I wouldn’t mind seeing 2017 books that are told in the form of letters. My review of Dracula explains why. In Dracula there are three narrators whose first person (or 3rd person in that case) narration of the events of Dracula is interrupted by 3rd person letters from the characters. That does a much better job of presenting the book than it might have if it had been written entirely in the 3rd person. That’s my point. I do like epistolary novels, even though most people seem to think they’re boring. But there’s a very strong epistolary novel genre that people are writing and it’s getting a lot better, even though it hasn’t come close to catching on. It’s a whole different style of the book. People think they’re all boring. I did an epistolary novel a while ago. It told the events through the letters of one main character, but the letters didn’t take place between chapters. They were scattered about, like a movie. So it was sort of an epistolary novel. The book was called The Third Dimension of Everything, and it did fairly well. I would like to write a whole epistolary novel, but not so much epistolary. If I did it now, it would definitely be written as email. But in the 90s, it would have been written as letters. They were pretty popular in the 90s and even in the 80s and 70s. But not so much at the present time when we’re doing a lot more and getting a lot more email. But I do remember that epistolary novels were extremely popular in the 80s. It did better than any of the best sellers. There was actually a whole era where books were written that way, and they were very popular. I even remember a book where the entire text was one long, single letter. So you never knew who was writing it. I do think that was successful. I hope someone does one of those types of books again, and just writes letters between the characters. It would be fun to do that. 9. What’s the most common problem that you see in your stories or books that you’ve written? I’m looking at some of my old work. (I’ll do another blog to talk about some of those specific things.) It’s very hard to write science fiction, as far as books go. It’s not easy at all to write science fiction short stories. I’ve done that too. The science fiction short story genre is extremely limited. Some people just throw together a lot of science fiction and think it’s science fiction and maybe it is. Maybe some of them are, but most of them are not. It’s not easy, if you write science fiction for a living, that people like what you’re writing. It’s not that easy. Some people are just really good at it, like Ray Bradbury, but most aren’t. I have a number of really talented friends who have really done a good job of writing science fiction. (You’ll remember Daisy, who’s writing a science fiction book, and some others who are writing science fiction books, too, that they’re publishing. They’ll probably all be published as well soon). But I don’t think that’ll ever be my thing. It’s really weird for me to say that because of my love for Ray.
